findings.title: Invalid vaultBuffer could revert allocate
findings.description: Lack of input validation when updating the vaultBuffer could cause token allocations inside allocate to revert.

findings.title: OUSD.changeSupply should require rebasingCreditsPerToken > 0
findings.description: ChangeSupply function does not validate that rebasingCreditsPerToken is non-zero, which could break invariants in the contract.

findings.title: SafeMath is recommended in OUSD._executeTransfer
findings.description: Using SafeMath for mathematical operations is recommended to prevent underflow or overflow issues.

findings.title: Transfers could silently fail without safeTransfer
findings.description: Functions do not check the ERC20.transfer return value, which may lead to unexpected results.

findings.title: Proxies are only partially EIP-1967-compliant
findings.description: The InitializeGovernedUpgradeabilityProxy contract does not fully comply with EIP-1967 standards.

findings.title: Queued transactions cannot be canceled
findings.description: The Governor contract contains special functions to set it as the admin of the Timelock, but there are no functions in Governor that call Timelock.cancelTransaction.

findings.title: Unused code could cause problems in future
findings.description: The three oracle contracts are not upgradeable, yet contain code meant for upgradeable contracts.

findings.title: Proposal transactions can be executed separately and block Proposal.execute call
findings.description: Missing access controls in the Timelock.executeTransaction function allow Proposal transactions to be executed separately, circumventing the Governor.execute function.

findings.title: Proposals could allow Timelock.admin takeover
findings.description: A regular Proposal is also allowed to contain a transaction to change the Timelock.admin, posing an unnecessary risk in that an attacker could create a Proposal to change the Timelock.admin.

findings.title: Reentrancy and untrusted contract call in mintMultiple
findings.description: Missing checks and no reentrancy prevention allow untrusted contracts to be called from mintMultiple, which could be used by an attacker to drain the contracts.

findings.title: Off-by-one minDrift / maxDrift causes unexpected revert
findings.description: The MixOracle contract contains an off-by-one in the checks that make use of the minDrift and maxDrift variables, causing an error to be generated when the price is exactly the minDrift or maxDrift.

findings.title: Unsafe last array element removal poses future risk
findings.description: Array length underflow when removing the last array element

findings.title: Strategy targetWeight can be set for non-existent strategy
findings.description: Setting targetWeight for a non-existent strategy

findings.title: Lack of minimum redeem value might lead to less return than expected
findings.description: Redeem fee deducted from the redeem amount inside the _calculateRedeemOutputs function

findings.title: Withdraw allows redeemer to withdraw accidentally sent tokens
findings.description: Withdraw function transfers the entire contractâ€™s token balance to the recipient instead of the requested amount

findings.title: Variable shadowing from OUSD to ERC20
findings.description: OUSD redefines _allowances and _totalSupply state variables, leading to unexpected behaviors

findings.title: VaultCore.rebase functions have no return statements
findings.description: rebase() and rebase(bool) return a uint but lack a return statement

findings.title: Multiple contracts are missing inheritances
findings.description: Several critical operations do not trigger events.

findings.title: External calls in loop can lead to denial of service
findings.description: Several function calls are made in unbounded loops.

findings.title: No events for critical operations
findings.description: Several critical operations do not trigger events.

findings.title: OUSD allows users to transfer more tokens than expected
findings.description: Under certain circumstances, the OUSD contract allows users to transfer more tokens than they have in their balance.

findings.title: OUSD total supply can be arbitrary, even smaller than user balances
findings.description: The OUSD token contract allows users to opt out of rebasing effects, leading to an inconsistent total supply.
